engagementHook.title: Did You Know?
engagementHook.content: There are more bacterial cells in your body than human cells! While human cells are larger, bacteria outnumber them by about 10 to 1. Most of these bacteria live in your gut and help with digestion.

contentSections.title: What are Prokaryotes?
contentSections.content:
Prokaryotes are single-celled organisms that lack a membrane-bound nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. The word comes from Greek: 'pro' meaning before, and 'karyon' meaning nut or kernel (referring to the nucleus).

There are two domains of prokaryotes: Bacteria and Archaea. While they look similar under a microscope, they have significant genetic and biochemical differences.

contentSections.title: Prokaryotic Cell Features
contentSections.definition: A cell lacking a membrane-bound nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. DNA is located in a region called the nucleoid.

contentSections.title: Binary Fission
contentSections.content:
Prokaryotes reproduce asexually through binary fission. This process is rapid and can occur every 20 minutes under ideal conditions.

The process:
items: The two DNA molecules move to opposite poles
The cell divides in the middle (cytokinesis)
Two identical daughter cells are formed

contentSections.title: Prokaryotes vs Eukaryotes
contentSections.content: Here are the key differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells:
items: Prokaryotes: No nucleus; Eukaryotes: Have nucleus
Prokaryotes: No membrane-bound organelles; Eukaryotes: Have organelles
Prokaryotes: Circular DNA; Eukaryotes: Linear DNA
Prokaryotes: Smaller ribosomes (70S); Eukaryotes: Larger ribosomes (80S)
Prokaryotes: Always unicellular; Eukaryotes: Can be unicellular or multicellular

activities.title: Activity 1: Structure & Function Matching
activities.description: Match each structure with its function:

definitions: Prokaryote: A cell without a membrane-bound nucleus or organelles
Nucleoid: The region in a prokaryotic cell where the circular DNA is located
Binary Fission: Asexual reproduction in prokaryotes where one cell divides into two identical cells
keyPoints: Prokaryotic cells have: cell wall, cell membrane, cytoplasm, ribosomes, nucleoid with DNA
Prokaryotes reproduce by binary fission every 20 minutes (under ideal conditions)
